doc.title: Meidensha (6508.T): Conference call: Spring power infra reassuring; watching for improvement in SPEProducEs, EV motors/inverters
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Meidensha 6508.T Conference call Strong power infra reassuring watching for improvement in SPE products EV motorsinverte_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: On August 28, we hosted an investor meeting with Mr. Daisuke Kuroiwa, Meidensha's Manager for Specialist Duty, Public & Investor Relations Section.

Overall, the picture remains unchanged, with the power infrastructure business performing well, mainly overseas, while the mobility and electrical components business struggles. The public, industrial & commercial business segment includes the defense business, which is small relative to companywide sales (FY3/26 companywide sales guidance: \(\) 335\(bn). Meidensha said that defense sales were\) \ \(3\) bn in FY3/25, are expected to be \(\) 6- 7\(bn in FY3/26, and it targets more than\) \ \(10\) bn in FY3/27. We believe that the power infrastructure business is likely to offset the weakness in the mobility and electrical components business relative to medium- term plan targets (sales\) \ \(370\) bn, operating profits \(\) 25\(bn).

Looking ahead, we will be watching for: 1) further price improvements in the power infrastructure business both in Japan and overseas, 2) the contribution of vacuum capacitors for SPE applications, which tend to perform well during upcycles, and 3) the timing of improvement in the EV motor/inverter business, where capacity utilization is currently low. Valuations have also improved, and we maintain our Neutral rating from a risk/reward perspective.
All based on company comments unless otherwise noted.

The company acknowledges that the medium- term management plan announced in May is based on conservative assumptions. Sell- side analysts have also pointed out the company's tendency to issue conservative guidance, and President Akio Inoue has said that he understands the need to provide more precise guidance.

Meidensha earnings tend to be concentrated in 2H in the field service engineering and power infrastructure segments, but the overseas ratio has been increasing in recent years, notably in the substation business, and the quarterly earnings trend is

Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA in the U.S.
leveling out. The company is transitioning to a situation in which sales and profits are booked throughout the year, making it easier to forecast quarterly earnings.

The company initially expected the impact of tariffs to be minor, and there has been no major change in this view. As of the end of 1Q, there were some advance orders for vacuum interrupters, but the direct impact has been limited to that. Meidensha said there has been no shift in demand to competitors in the US. In terms of indirect impact, the company said it has not heard of any extensions of investment plans on the customer side.

In terms of regional trends in the power infrastructure business, 1Q results in Singapore exceeded expectations. The company had expected orders to decline significantly yoy due to its inability to bid on some projects this year due to penalties, but as of 1Q, margins had not deteriorated relative to the company's expectations, and it achieved an operating margin of over \(20\%\) . The company expects orders to improve from 2Q and expects margins to remain in the \(20\%\) range for the full year.

The US business continues to perform well, and 1Q sales were \(\yen 2.7\) bn higher than planned due to some advance orders. The company said it is likely to exceed its initial full- year forecast, and it expects margins to be just under \(10\%\) .
In India, there have been delays due to late deliveries from suppliers, and Meidensha expects the operating margin to deteriorate, but it expects it to exceed \(10\%\) over the full year.
In Germany, the company achieved an operating margin of over \(10\%\) in 1Q, and expects this level to continue for the full year.

Profitability is also gradually improving in business for domestic electric power companies. Meidensha expects significant yoy growth in FY3/26 due to projects postponed from the previous year and orders for large- scale hydropower projects, but it expects sales and profits to fall back yoy in FY3/27. However, current orders exceed \(\yen 40\) bn, and the business remains on a high plateau.

Meidensha set a medium- term target of \(\yen 95\) bn in sales and \(\yen 3.5\) bn in operating profits in FY3/28 for the mobility and electrical components business, but said it will likely be difficult to achieve these targets. In the EV motor/inverter business, the company said that the current weakness is continuing due to the slowdown in the shift to EVs, and although it is working to reduce costs through personnel transfers, etc., it is difficult to significantly improve the business.

Meidensha said it now expects the recovery to be later than its initial assumption of 2H this fiscal year, as the volume of orders from end customer Tokyo Electron has declined. Regarding the strong 1Q results for Daimen's SPE power supply business, the company said that there may be a time lag in vacuum capacitor inventory that Meidensha delivered to Dainen. The company also said that 1Q orders from US customer Applied Materials fell short of plan, and it will need to keep an eye on order trends from 2Q onward.

In the motor and drive systems business, while the company expects demand for forklift and injection molding machine applications to be in line with the previous year, demand for textile and elevator applications is currently sluggish due to the downturn in the Chinese market. Dynamo orders increased significantly in FY3/25 due to the slowdown in the shift to EVs, but it expects orders in FY3/26 to fall back to half the previous year's level.
The company said that although it received unexpected orders in 1Q, the labor shortage in the construction field is continuing, and it is unclear how much it will be able to book as sales in FY3/26.

Meidensha's defense- related business, in the public, industrial & commercial segment, mainly supplies mobile power generators, emergency power supplies, and substation equipment. According to the company, sales in the defense business were ¥3 bn in FY3/25, are expected to be ¥6- 7 bn in FY3/26, and are targeted to exceed ¥10 bn in FY3/27. Margins in the defense business are higher than those in the public, industrial & commercial segment as a whole, with mobile power generators and emergency power supplies generating relatively high margins.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
